4.text:
Every year on June 4th, thousands of people
rally throughout China in remembrance of a

9.text:
1989 violent government crackdown. To this
day, the Chinese government refuses to acknowledge

14.text:
the event, and any information about it is
blocked from the internet and public record.

19.text:
So what happened? Here’s a timeline of the
Tiananmen Square massacre.

23.text:
[1966-1976] China’s Cultural Revolution
leads to the persecution of millions and encourages

28.text:
a cult of personality around communist leader
Mao Zedong.

32.text:
[April 15, 1989] A publicly progressive, but
politically controversial official, Hu Yaobang

37.text:
dies. Subsequent memorials become hotbeds
of citizen dissatisfaction with the Communist

43.text:
[April 26, 1989] An editorial in the official
Communist Party newspaper seeks to end student

47.text:
protests by warning that they are detrimental
to the success of the country. The editorial

53.text:
backfires and strengthens the resolve of protest
groups.

56.text:
[May 19, 1989] Tiananmen square draws an estimated
1.2 million people for an anti-government

62.text:
rally. In response, the government imposes
martial law.

65.text:
[June 4, 1989] Soldiers open fire on unarmed
student protesters. The death toll is disputed,

71.text:
but unofficial estimates place it as high
as several thousand. About 10,000 protesters

77.text:
[June 5, 1989] Chinese tanks make their way
down the middle of Tiananmen Square and are

81.text:
stopped by an unidentified man standing in
front of them, today known as “Tank Man”.

84.text:
His actions are still used to represent nonviolent
government rebellion.

89.text:
It’s been 26 years since the 1989 Tiananmen
Square violence, and there are still protests

94.text:
happening against the Chinese government.
The 2011 pro-democracy protests, and the 2014

100.text:
riots in Hong Kong serve to illustrate how
China’s current popular unrest mirrors and

106.text:
builds off of the same foundation that was
created by the students of the 1989 protests.

112.text:
To learn about just how bad censorship in
China is, take a look at our full video here.

117.text:
Thanks for watching TestTube News. Please
subscribe so you don’t miss a single video.
